awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ecology, biology, and coexistence among multiple species of human ancestors
awd_abstract_narration:
Variation in the human fossil record from sites in eastern Africa is too great to be attributed to one hominin species. It has been suggested that up to five hominin species – Paranthropus boisei, Homo habilis, Homo rudolfensis, Homo ergaster, and Homo erectus ¬– overlapped in space, time and in the dietary resources consumed. This project identifies the extent and type of competition between eastern African P. boisei and early Homo during the Pleistocene (after c. 2.5 mya). Understanding how early Homo responded to competition with other species at this critical early stage in the history of our genus allows us to better appreciate our own anatomy, behavior and plasticity. This study also has broader implications for ecological and biological research. Character displacement, which is one of the factors that enables the coexistence of closely related species, influences the structure of ecological communities, and helps drive speciation and the distribution of biodiversity. The project also creates lesson plans with education experts in the United States and internationally and supports the training of a woman scholar.

The researchers use 3D geometric morphometric (GM) shape-change analysis to test whether interspecific competition influenced the evolution of our genus Homo through time, and whether there were any significant morphological effects of this competition. Conventional wisdom suggested that early Homo led to the extinction of P. boisei over time through competitive exclusion. However, this project applies an updated 3D GM shape-change analysis methodology to test for ecological niche incumbency, a type of competition hypothesis that has not typically been considered in paleoanthropology. The investigators use molar morphological evidence from over a million years in P. boisei and early Homo to investigate the nature and potential causes of any interspecific competition. The results of this study may provide evidence of competition between these genera through time and transform previous narratives of Homo exceptionalism by showing how a non-ancestral hominin may have influenced the trajectory of our own ancestral lineage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In my completed dissertation, funded by this DDRIG, I show how the current fossil and paleoecological evidence for Paranthropus and Homo is consistent with alternative scenarios in which a non-ancestral lineage can significantly impact the evolution of a surviving lineage. I verify that early Homo and Paranthropus were not merely in the same place at the same time, but were actively interacting with each other (i.e., functional sympatry). This is tested quantitatively through Hutchinson’s rule, where the ratio between mastication-related linear measurements can signal whether sympatric species have adequately niche-partitioned along their dietary axes. Lastly, I used 3D geometric morphometrics on over 130 Paranthropus and early Homo fossils scanned at the National Museums of Kenya to differentiate between ecological niche incumbency and character displacement, two potential manifestations of competition that could have occurred between eastern African hominins during the Pleistocene. This dissertation provides a shift in our theoretical frameworks as they apply to competition between hominins in eastern Africa and shows how a non-ancestral, non-surviving lineage can significantly impact the evolutionary lineage of our own genus: Homo. 

The potential for competition between Paranthropus boisei and early Homo in eastern Africa has previously been explored through the relatively narrow lens of character displacement and competitive exclusion. This project suggests that the relative stasis in P. boisei is more consistent with an alternative form of competition, such as ecological niche incumbency, where there was an asymmetric displacement of the attempted colonizer through pre-sympatric niche divergence. In this scenario, the ecological niche incumbency of P. boisei could have influenced the evolution of early Homo by causing it to explore alternative niches.

I do not find evidence to support the narrative that early Homo was a stronger competitor who eventually pushed P. boisei to extinction over time. Instead, early Homo appears to change significantly and consistently through time while P. boisei the ecological incumbent, remained in morphological stasis. Therefore, their extinction would have likely been caused by environmental, stochastic, and/or demographic variables rather than through direct competition with early Homo. Given the lack of evidence of character displacement between these genera found in this dissertation, it is unlikely that Homo was a major influence on the extinction of P. boisei. It is true that P. boisei disappears from the fossil record without leaving any likely descendants, but that does not preclude it from having a profound influence on human evolution during their long-lasting existence.

The main goal of this research was to explore previously unconsidered alternative hypotheses for hominin interaction and compare them through multiple lines of evidence and different methodologies. This dissertation has highlighted that ignoring ecologically valid, potentially relevant hypotheses in paleoanthropological research due to the pre-conceived narrative that Homo had, and always will have, a competitive advantage regardless of the environmental context, simply because one of their species survived until present day, is not a valid assumption. Only until we move away from hominin, or more specifically Homo, exceptionalism will we be able to glean a clearer picture of our origins, interactions, and evolution.

 

Broader Impacts

This project not only affects how other paleoanthropologists conduct their research on human evolution going forward, but alters the previously disseminated narrative about how human evolution occurred, affecting the public’s view on our own evolutionary history. This project has implications for evolutionary biology, functional anatomy, cognitive neuroscience, and archaeological tool use due to its restructuring of the narrative of what it means to be human, and how we got to where we are through the lens of our sympatric species over time.

            This project created over 250 high resolution, textured 3D scans of hominin fossils from the National Museums of Kenya, which are free to access with the proper permits from the National Museums of Kenya. I also trained three Kenyan research assistants in 3D scanning, photogrammetry, and 3D geometric morphometrics during my time at the National Museums of Kenya. I also trained over a dozen undergrad, masters, and PhD students in 3D scanning and geometric morphometrics when I returned to the George Washington University in DC. The results from this project were presented as a podium presentation at the 2024 American Association of Biological Anthropologists conference in Los Angeles, CA, and are in revision for publication(s) as well.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2024
Modified by: Alexis S Uluutku
